verses.text: Amaziah was twenty-five years old when he became king, and he reigned twenty-nine years in Jerusalem. His mother’s name was Jehoaddan of Jerusalem.
verses.comment: Closely follows original. Retains original ages and names.

verses.text: He did what was right in the eyes of the LORD, but not with a whole heart.
verses.comment: Emphasizes his incomplete devotion, as in the Hebrew.

verses.text: When the kingdom was firmly in his control, he put to death his servants who had killed his father the king.
verses.comment: Follows original; “strengthened himself” rendered as “firmly in his control.”

verses.text: But he did not put their children to death, as it is written in the Law, in the Book of Moses, where the LORD commanded, 'Fathers shall not be put to death for their children, nor shall children be put to death for their fathers, but each one shall die for his own sin.'
verses.comment: Direct quotation from the Law maintained.

verses.text: Amaziah assembled Judah and appointed them by fathers’ houses under commanders of thousands and of hundreds for all Judah and Benjamin. He counted those twenty years old and up and found three hundred thousand choice men, able to go out to war, skilled with spear and shield.
verses.comment: Literal translation of military census.

verses.text: He also hired one hundred thousand mighty men of valor from Israel for a hundred talents of silver.
verses.comment: ‘Men of valor’ and ‘talents of silver’ kept literal.

verses.text: But a man of God came to him and said, 'O king, do not let the army of Israel go with you, for the LORD is not with Israel, with any of the Ephraimites.'
verses.comment: ‘Man of God’ and ‘Ephraimites’ left as in original.

verses.text: If you go, act, be strong for battle, God will make you fall before the enemy, for God has the power to help and to cause someone to fall.
verses.comment: Preserves literal warning.

verses.text: Amaziah said to the man of God, 'But what should I do about the hundred talents that I gave to the army of Israel?' The man of God answered, 'The LORD is able to give you much more than this.'
verses.comment: Careful to render exchange naturally while keeping literal sense.

verses.text: So Amaziah discharged the troops that came to him from Ephraim, and they returned home very angry with Judah.
verses.comment: ‘Sent them home in anger’ kept clear and concise.

verses.text: But Amaziah took courage and led his people out to the Valley of Salt. There he struck down ten thousand men of Seir.
verses.comment: ‘Men of Seir’ refer to Edomites. Valley of Salt kept literal.

verses.text: The men of Judah captured another ten thousand alive, and brought them to the top of a cliff. They threw them down from the top, so they all were dashed to pieces.
verses.comment: Brutality retained as factual description.

verses.text: But the men of the army whom Amaziah sent back, who were not allowed to go with him to battle, raided the cities of Judah from Samaria to Beth-horon, killed three thousand people there, and took their large amount of plunder.
verses.comment: ‘Spoil’ rendered as plunder for clarity.

verses.text: After Amaziah came from striking down the Edomites, he brought the gods of the men of Seir and set them up as his own gods. He bowed down before them and burned incense to them.
verses.comment: ‘Gods of the people of Seir’ understood as Edomite idols.

verses.text: Therefore, the LORD’s anger burned against Amaziah. He sent him a prophet, who said to him, 'Why have you sought the gods of these people who could not deliver their own people from your hand?'
verses.comment: Question worded to suit modern English, but stays literal.

verses.text: But as he spoke, the king said to him, 'Have we made you an advisor to the king? Stop! Why should you be struck down?' So the prophet stopped, but said, 'I know that God has determined to destroy you, because you have done this and have not listened to my advice.'
verses.comment: Direct speech retained, vividness preserved.

verses.text: Then Amaziah king of Judah took counsel and sent messengers to Jehoash son of Jehoahaz, son of Jehu, king of Israel, saying, 'Come, let us face each other in battle.'
verses.comment: 'See one another’s face' rendered as 'face each other in battle' for clarity.

verses.text: Jehoash king of Israel sent back to Amaziah king of Judah, 'The thistle that was in Lebanon sent to the cedar that was in Lebanon, saying,
verses.comment: Proverbial language kept literal—thistle and cedar.

verses.text: "Give your daughter to my son as wife." Then a wild beast of Lebanon passed by and trampled the thistle.' 'You say,
verses.comment: Continuation of parable from verse 18.

verses.text: You say,
verses.comment: Maintains reference to parable and connection to Edom victory.

verses.text: But Amaziah would not listen, for this was from God, that He might deliver them into Jehoash’s hand, because they had sought the gods of Edom.
verses.comment: Cause-effect from God highlighted as in the Hebrew.

verses.text: So Jehoash king of Israel went up, and he and Amaziah king of Judah faced each other at Beth-shemesh, which belongs to Judah.
verses.comment: Literal location given, 'went up' kept as in text.

verses.text: Judah was defeated by Israel, and each man fled to his tent.
verses.comment: 'Fled to his tent' is a Hebrew idiom for fleeing home.

verses.text: Jehoash king of Israel captured Amaziah king of Judah, the son of Jehoash, son of Jehoahaz, at Beth-shemesh, and brought him to Jerusalem. He broke down the wall of Jerusalem from the Ephraim Gate to the Corner Gate, four hundred cubits.
verses.comment: Wall dimensions given in cubits per original.

verses.text: He took all the gold and silver, and all the vessels found in the house of God with Obed-edom, and the treasures of the king’s house, also hostages, and returned to Samaria.
verses.comment: 'Hostages' is literal for 'children of the pledges.'

verses.text: Amaziah the son of Joash king of Judah lived fifteen years after the death of Jehoash the son of Jehoahaz, king of Israel.
verses.comment: Genealogy and timeline echoed verbatim.

verses.text: Now from the time that Amaziah turned away from following the LORD, they made a conspiracy against him in Jerusalem, and he fled to Lachish. But they sent after him to Lachish and killed him there.
verses.comment: Conspiracy and assassination are retained as in the Hebrew.

verses.text: They brought him back on horses and buried him with his fathers in the city of Judah.
verses.comment: 'City of Judah' is alternative reading of 'city of David' in some MSS; included for textual faithfulness.
